bestBHT.bht: Jesus sternly charged his disciples to keep quiet about his true identity as the Messiah, laying a penalty upon them if they were to disobey. He specifically commanded them to tell no one about it, as its implications could lead to political unrest among the Jews. This prohibition on openly proclaiming his Messiahship was necessary, as seen in the aftermath of the feeding of the five thousand, when the people sought to make Jesus their earthly king. Jesus recognized that such a declaration by his disciples would spark a revolution, which was not the purpose of his ministry on earth.

Marvin Vincent: He straitly charged [επιτιμησας] . The word implies an emphatic, solemn charge; its meaning being, strictly, to lay a penalty upon one, and thence, to charge under penalty.
No man [μηδενι] . The conditional negative: no man, whoever he might be.
Archibald T. Robertson: To tell this to no man (μηδεν λεγειν τουτο). Indirect command with the negative infinitive after commanded (παρηγγειλεν).
It had been necessary for Jesus to cease using the word Messiah (Χριστος) about himself because of the political meaning to the Jews.
Its use by the disciples would lead to revolution as was plain after the feeding of the five thousand (John 6:15).
John Gill: Though he highly approved of this their confession, and pronounced Peter blessed upon it; and signified that it was a discovery which flesh and blood could not make, but what was made to him his Father...
[Jesus] gave them a strict charge, and laid his commands on them, to tell no man that thing...

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus sternly charged his disciples to keep quiet about his true identity as the Messiah, laying a penalty upon them if they were to disobey. He specifically commanded them to tell no one about it, as its implications could lead to political unrest among the Jews. This prohibition on openly proclaiming his Messiahship was necessary, as seen in the aftermath of the feeding of the five thousand, when the people sought to make Jesus their earthly king. Jesus recognized that such a declaration by his disciples would spark a revolution, which was not the purpose of his ministry on earth.

Jesus emphatically charged his disciples, under penalty, not to disclose his identity as the Messiah. This command applied to all people, without exception. It was essential for Jesus to cease using the term Messiah because of its political connotations among the Jews. The disciples' use of this title would have incited revolution, as evidenced in the aftermath of the miraculous feeding of the five thousand. Therefore, Jesus strictly instructed them not to reveal his true nature as the Messiah.

Jesus gave a solemn and strict charge to his disciples, emphatically commanding them not to disclose his identity as the Messiah. This prohibition was necessary because the term Messiah carried political implications among the Jews. The disciples' use of this title would have led to a revolt, evident from the aftermath of the miraculous feeding of the five thousand. Therefore, Jesus laid a penalty upon them, instructing them to keep his true nature as the Messiah a secret.

Jesus strongly commanded his disciples, under penalty, not to disclose his identity as the Messiah. This strict charge applied to everyone, without exception. The disciples were forbidden from openly proclaiming Jesus as the Messiah due to the political implications it held among the Jews. Jesus recognized that such a declaration by his followers could potentially incite revolution, as seen after the miraculous feeding of the five thousand. Therefore, he emphatically instructed them to keep his true nature as the Messiah a secret.

Jesus commanded his disciples, under penalty, not to reveal that he was the Messiah. This charge applied universally, without exception. The use of the term Messiah carried political implications among the Jews, making it necessary for Jesus to cease using it to describe himself. Openly proclaiming his Messiahship would have led to revolution, as evidenced after the miracle of the feeding of the five thousand. Therefore, Jesus sternly instructed his disciples to keep his true identity as the Messiah a secret.
